headline: Screw the money — Anthropic’s $1.5B copyright settlement sucks for writers
summary: Writers aren't getting this settlement because their work was fed to an AI -- this is just a costly slap on the wrist for Anthropic because it illegally downloaded books instead of buying them.

headline: Meta’s Backstop Is Linchpin for $26 Billion AI Data-Center Deal
summary: The financing is being run through a complex arrangement that keeps the debt off of Meta’s books and frees up its balance sheet as it pursues an aggressive push into artificial intelligence.  A joint venture will actually build and own the 4-million-square-foot Hyperion facility, while Meta will occupy and use the data center under a 20-year lease.

headline: Anthropic agrees to pay $1.5 billion to settle author class action
summary: (Reuters) -Anthropic told a San Francisco federal judge on Friday that it has agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit from a group of authors who accused the artificial intelligence company of using their books to train its AI chatbot Claude without permission.  The plaintiffs in a court filing asked U.S. District Judge William Alsup to approve the settlement, after announcing the agreement in August without disclosing the terms or amount.  "This settlement sends a powerful message to AI companies and creators alike that taking copyrighted works from these pirate websites is wrong,” the authors' lawyers said in a statement.

raw.headline: Anthropic agrees to pay $1.5 billion to settle author class action
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Anthropic told a San Francisco federal judge on Friday that it has agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit from a group of authors who accused the artificial intelligence company of using their books to train its AI chatbot Claude without permission.  The plaintiffs in a court filing asked U.S. District Judge William Alsup to approve the settlement, after announcing the agreement in August without disclosing the terms or amount.  "This settlement sends a powerful message to AI companies and creators alike that taking copyrighted works from these pirate websites is wrong,” the authors' lawyers said in a statement.

headline: Trump warns Big Tech CEOs of 'substantial' tariffs at WH dinner
summary: Big Tech executives continue cozying up to President Trump, with Meta (META) CEO Mark Zuckerberg, OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) CEO Sam Altman, and Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook having attended a White House dinner on Thursday. Trump warned of "substantial" tariffs on semiconductors at the dinner. Yahoo Finance Tech Editor Dan Howley examines the tech executives' ongoing diplomacy efforts with the Trump administration. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Why AMD (AMD) Shares Are Sliding Today
summary: Shares of computer processor maker AMD (NASDAQ:AMD) fell 5.3% in the afternoon session after the company was downgraded by Seaport Research due to concerns about slowing growth in its artificial intelligence (AI) business. The investment firm lowered its rating on the chipmaker to Neutral from Buy, with no price target, based on recent supply chain checks. These checks suggested slowing growth and difficulty in expanding orders for its AI accelerator business.

headline: What AI Bubble? Vistra Makes A Powerful Run As AI Data Centers Fuel Nuclear Growth.
summary: After rocketing 258% higher last year — placing it among the top S&P 500 stocks and the best 100 stocks of 2024 — Vistra stock has galloped higher in 2025 amid the AI data center boom.  Nuclear giants Vistra and Constellation Energy are both up almost 40% in this year's stock market, continuing to build momentum since last year.  Analysts proclaim there is a "nuclear renaissance" underway.

headline: AI Can Help With Retirement Planning, but It Can’t Replace a Human Advisor
summary: Haywood Talcove recently tasked his financial advisors and ChatGPT with reviewing the portfolio he manages for his mother, Dotty, an 84-year-old widow.  The human advisors gave the portfolio a once-over and offered a simple qualitative assessment, while the AI offered a more detailed analysis, including a breakdown of the different sectors represented and the income Dotty receives from each of her dividend stocks.  “I have much more confidence in AI,” says Talcove, CEO of government business at LexisNexis Risk Solutions, who employs two major financial firms he declined to name to manage his own money.

headline: Trump Basks in Tech Leaders’ Spending Vows at White House Dinner
summary: In his opening remarks, Trump addressed a key concern of tech companies: ensuring there’s enough energy to meet surging power demands from the data centers behind the AI boom.  Thursday’s dinner marked a rare gathering in Washington of top executives and founders from some of the world’s most valuable tech companies — all vying for an edge in the emerging field of AI.
